thread.title: S&P 500 Futures Little Changed; JPMorgan, Intel Fall on Earnings
thread.title_full: S&P 500 Futures Little Changed; JPMorgan, Intel Fall on Earnings - Bloomberg Business

author: Bloomberg.com
title: S&P 500 Futures Little Changed; JPMorgan, Intel Fall on Earnings
text:
U.S. stock-index futures were little changed amid another round of corporate earnings, while weak data out of China sent shares lower in Europe and Asia.
JPMorgan Chase & Co., the first big bank to report this season, fell 1.6 percent in premarket trading after earnings missed analyst targets and the bank cautioned that trading this quarter is off to a tepid start. Intel Corp. lost 2.6 percent after saying a slowdown in demand threatens to curb sales at its server-chip division. SanDisk Corp. surged 11 percent after it was said to hire a bank to explore a potential sale.
Standard & Poor’s 500 Index E-mini contracts expiring in December added less than 0.1 percent to 1994.25 at 7:15 a.m. in New York . Dow Jones Industrial Average contracts added 2 points to 16,975.
“This is the calm before the storm of earnings and investors are still waiting to get a clearer picture of how companies view the final quarter of the year,” said Hugh Grieves, who runs the U.S. Opportunities Fund at Miton Group in London. “Hopefully, a clearer picture will emerge as more companies report.”
Wells Fargo & Co., Delta Air Lines Inc. and Netflix Inc. report results today. Analysts project earnings for S&P 500 members dropped 7.2 percent in the third quarter. Bank of America Corp. added 1.4 percent after saying quarterly profit rebounded.
Asian and European shares fell today after a report showed China’s factory gate deflation extended a record stretch of declines while inflation moderated. Weak imports data out of China sent the S&P 500 lower yesterday, while selling picked up in biotechnology stocks.
“The probability of a global recession is rising as news out of China gets worse,” Grieves said. “As each data point comes out, positive or negative, sentiment lurches from one extreme to the other very quickly.”
Investors will also look to today’s September retail sales reports for clues on how recent market turmoil has affected consumer sentiment. Also due today -- the Beige Book survey, which provides anecdotal information about the economy based on reports from regional banks. Federal Reserve meeting minutes last week signaled caution over raising interest rates even as the economy improves, spurring traders to pare their bets for a rate move this year.
